original_title: Biggest crossing by a company on a particular day; turnover hits Rs 17 billion
original_body_lines: CSE activities were dominated by HNB yesterday, because out of 53.1 percent (Non- Voting) shares held by Browns Investments, 38.5 million shares were sold to 207 investors by way of an arranged transaction or crossing, thus registering the biggest crossing made by a single company in a day, market analysts said.

Browns Investments sold below the previous day’s market price of Rs 280, resulting in the market coming down despite the whopping turnover of Rs 17 billion, enabling the market to perform in a downward trend.
The All Share Price Index went down by 61.3 points while S and P SL20 declined by 43.45 points. Turnover stood at Rs 17 billion with six crossings.

Those crossings were reported in HNB (Non- Voting) 38.5 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 10 billion; its shares traded at Rs 280, HNB (Voting) 1.95 million share volumes crossed for Rs 702 million and its shares traded at Rs 360, JKH 8.9 million shares crossed for Rs 230 million; its shares traded at Rs 25.60, Access Engineering 1.9 million share volumes crossed to the tune of Rs 110 million and its shares traded at Rs 58, Distilleries 990,000 shares crossed for Rs 44.6 million; its shares sold at Rs 45 and Lanka IOC 185,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 24.2 million; its shares traded at Rs 131.

In the retail market, the top companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; HNB (Voting) Rs 515 million (1.4 million shares traded), Sampath Bank Rs 327 million (2.3 million shares traded), JKH Rs 308 million (12 million shares traded), Browns Investments Rs 274 million (35 million shares traded), Access Engineering Rs 243 million (4.2 million shares traded) and HNB (Non- Voting) Rs 232 million (804,000 shares traded). During the day 301 million share volumes changed hands in 38172 transactions.

It is said that the banking sector, especially HNB crossings, and retail trade contributed more than 89 percent to the turnover and the manufacturing sector was the second largest contributor, especially JKH. Further, mixed reactions were noted in services and other sectors.

Seylan Bank PLC debenture issue to raise up to 15 billion rupees was oversubscribed, according to a stock exchange filing. The bank had received 158 applications totaling 23,882,010,000, its sources said. The rupee-denominated, Basel III-compliant subordinated debentures were offered at Rs 100 each.

Yesterday the rupee opened at Rs 301.35/55 to the US dollar in the spot market, weaker from 301.00/15 a day earlier, while bond yields edged up. In the secondary market, a bond maturing on 15.12.2026 was quoted at 8.10/20 percent, from 8.05/15 percent.

A bond maturing on 15.09.2027 was quoted at 8.45/55 percent, flat. A bond maturing on 15.12.2028 was quoted at 8.98/9.00 percent. A bond maturing on 15.10.2029 was quoted at 9.48/50 percent. A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted at 9.50/53 percent, marginally up from 9.48/52 percent. A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.36/46 percent. A bond maturing on 01.06.2033 was quoted at 10.67/75 percent, from 10.70/90 percent. A bond maturing on 15.09.2034 was quoted at 10.85/95 percent.
